required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Propofol and Sevoflurane on Early POCD in Elderly Patients With Metabolic Syndrome
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Propofol and Sevoflurane on Early Postoperative Cognitive Dysfunction in Elderly Patients With Metabolic Syndrome

lead_sponsor.agency: General Hospital of Ningxia Medical University

clinical_study.source: General Hospital of Ningxia Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate propofol versus sevoflurane anesthesia on the effects of early postoperative cognitive function in elderly patients with metabolic syndrome.

detailed_description.textblock: By now, a series risk factors of cardiovascular diseases, which are also related to the development of postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD), are becoming more common.The investigators don't know whether propofol based anesthesia has a more severe impact on early postoperative cognitive function than sevoflurane in elderly patients with metabolic syndrome. In this study, the investigators want to investigate propofol versus sevoflurane anesthesia on the effects of early postoperative cognitive function in elderly patients with metabolic syndrome.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with Postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) as assessed by Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score in propofol group and sevoflurane group

arm_group.description: Patients with metabolic syndrome were randomly assigned to receive propofol anesthesia
Patients with metabolic syndrome were randomly assigned to receive sevoflurane anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- aged ≥60 years;
- ASAⅡor Ⅲ
- noncardiac surgery and nonneural surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Mini Mental State Examination [MMSE] score too low
- chronic alcoho and drug abuse
- disturbed renal and liver function
- history of a cerebrovascular accident
- permanent ventricular pacing
- preoperative cognitive deficits
- lack of cooperation
